roles/oooci-build-images/tasks/main.yaml.message: Please don't do that and use the "file" module.

While I do recommend this most time, I would challenge you to find some *measurable* benefits in doing so.

Using file module in that case would add extra seconds to runtime and make the output even more verbose (minor effects on logging too, but the pile-up in time).

Years of Ansible development taught me one thing: "pure-ansible" way is a path which guarantees only pain, nothing else, thus I slowly seen myself moving towards a more pragmatic approach (and nope, I am not in favour of writing big inline bash blocks either)

This patch and the other one (scenario manager one) are not dependent in a sense that one patch would need the changes of the other one in order to work. So you don't have to make them dependent if you don't want to.

However, as the 2 reviews edits the same file, it's likely that if one of the reviews merges the other will throw a merge conflict error and a rebase will be needed (that happens only in cases when gerrit can't do that rebase itself and has troubles understanding the order of the changes).

In order to avoid the mentioned conflict error you can (don't have to) make one of the patches dependent on the other one, here's a doc regarding dependent reviews: https://docs.opendev.org/opendev/infra-manual/latest/developers.html#adding-a-dependency

Adding one patch as dependent on the other one in order to avoid merge conflicts has it's pros and cons, so it's entirely on the owner of the patches ..

I mean under the elif block. eg:

            elif load.state == 'imported' or load.state == 'error':
                req_info['load_id'] = load.id
                req_info['load_version'] = load.software_version
                sysinv_client.delete_load(load_id_to_be_deleted)
                req_info['type'] = LOAD_DELETE_REQUEST_TYPE
                self._wait_for_request_to_complete(strategy_step, req_info)

The design intent of this step is to import the N+1 load for a legitimate/normal upgrade. If the subcloud happens to have an extra load, it will remove this load prior to importing another one. It should not be used as a mechanism to delete load when the subcloud already has N+1 load. The scenario in which the subcloud already has N+1 load:

a) subcloud has not been upgraded but N+1 load was manually imported in the subcloud.
b) subcloud has been upgraded to N+1 and N+2 load was manually imported in the subcloud.
c) orchestration failed after the importing load step and this is a retry

for a) and c) the N load will be removed in deleting load step, b) should not occur unless the sysinv database is modified to cause load mismatch so that the subcloud can be added to the strategy.

I know. I already explained why it was intentionally coded that way with the 3 example scenarios. If there are 2 loads and one of them is the N+1 load, the N/extra load will not be deleted here but at the end.

distributedcloud/dcmanager/rpc/client.py.message:
We shouldn't be defining the RPC API for cert_mon in the distcloud code. I see two options here:
1. Move this definition to cert_mon (i.e. sysinv/cert_mon directory).
2. Make this class (and the topic) generic - something like DCManagerNotifications class (and dcmanager-notifications topic). That way other components could listen to these notifications in the future.

I prefer option 2.
how are the corresponding symmetric subcloud_offline and subcloud_unmanaged cases handled by cert-mon?  Or are those reports being ignored on the dcmanager side.

cert-mon doesn't care offline and unmanaged events. When an audit finds out out-of-sync, it then check subcloud state to decided if it should update subcloud dc-cert status to "out-of-sync". Typically even an unmanaged subcloud can be in-sync for very long time (months)

Why does this really need? If we use domain scope then we've specified domain_name in credetial object.If we want to use project token let us specify it in credential.

Actually this patch addresses 2 issues.
1. To support domain-scoped rally deployment. 
    With this fix, new projects and users for the same can
    be created within the domain.
    The defect captures only this issue.
2. With the domain-scoped deployments, some component's test
   cases will fail with the error "internal endpoint for   
   compute service not found".(nova error)
   Why this fails: Many openstack components don’t register
   endpoints for domain-scoped tokens. The service catalog 
   returned from a domain-scoped request contains all 
   endpoints EXCLUDING ones that require a project ID as 
   part of their URL. ie, if the endpoint contains 
   PROJECT_ID as part of the URL, we get an empty list with 
   the domain-scoped tokens.
   We can not authenticate to multiple targets, it has  
   to be either project or domain. So we can not specify  
   both project-name and domain-name during deployment. It
   will fail as mentioned in the defect. 
   So to address the endpoint URL issue, I have explicitly 
   project-scoped the “admin” token for components facing
   the above mentioned problem. In the patch, I have 
   generalized this change to avoid changes everywhere. 

   This is not captured in the defect. I didn't want to 
   create a new defect as this defect can't be closed 
   without addressing this issue. That's why I have added
   all these details in the commit message. Please, let me  
   know if you need more info..

Thank you so much for your time in reviewing this patch:)

Those domain or project scope token will be created inside Passsword() implicitly. We don't need to construct it by hand. All that we need is to pass right args into Passsword() with domain info(to say keystoneauth to create Password obj based on domain scoped token) or project related info(to say keystoneauth to create Password obj based on project scoped token).
And..., those info(for domain or project scope token) we specify by hand through the deployment config. As I see in http://docs.openstack.org/developer/keystone/configuration.html#operation_create_project_scoped_token
we proceed all needed arguments from deployment config into credential. So I don't understand why we change something except deployment schema(and possibly a few related places) and adding friendly msg when both project and domain scoped info is available

Yes, you are right. But in case of domain scoped deployments discovering endpoints is not possible without project ids. Hence, we need project id's (in this case I have used admin project id) and have to switch to project scope for discovering the endpoints.
We've set PROJECT scope in credential object if tenant_name is not None

In case of domain scoped deployments, it is changed to PROJECT

reference/projects.yaml.message: We generally tag Oslo deliverables with stable:follows-policy too.
Ack, thanks for the insight. I like to be explicit so I amended this now.
Oh, I figured adding the tag right away would be dishonest. But yeah, we can follow up and add it at any time you wish.

At various times I've gotten feedback pushing in both directions. I prefer to just assert it up front since the Oslo team has a history of following stable policy and there's no reason to believe we won't with new deliverables too. That also saves a followup governance change to add it, which is likely to be forgotten.

That said, I don't care overly much about whether the tag is on a single project. I think it's well established that Oslo follows stable policy so if one project is not explicitly marked as such it's not likely to cause much confusion.

cinder/api/v3/views/volumes.py.message: I wonder whether we should not include the cluster_name at all if the value is None for people who are running cinder in the traditional active-passive configuration.

1) I agree it's a bit confusing for deployments without A/A.
2) cluster_name will be always set in A/A mode if the volume is successfully created, so None value will be combined with some error state.

Taking into account it's supposed to be admin-only API, I prefer to have the same response schema for all situations to make automation on top of it less complicated.


I assume that operators know what is A/A and why we've got cluster_name=None every time for non-A/A deployment
I was thinking about it but we didn't have a good way to do it from the API side because it's a cinder-volume configuration

1) I don't think this would be confusing. An admin should likely know if they are running HA or not. So a cluster_name of None shouldn't be any surprise to them.

That said, my first reaction was Brian's original comment of not including cluster_name in the results. I'd rather not send meaningless data across the wire. Really, I would be fine with either excluding it, or returning cluster_name: None, but my preference would be to exclude it.

One nit: return of get() is None if the value does not exist, so drop the ", None" part of the call. Should fit on one line then too.

I think it's best to just include it, even if it's None, just to have a consistent API.  Having a cluster_name set to None when not in A/A makes sense to me.  There is no clustering, so the name should be None.  And not having it show up in the details makes me think something is wrong.

I will put my two cents here.  Before my more recent experience I would have agreed that we shouldn't show it.  Though, based on what I have seen lately I think it is better to provide consistent information even if some is extraneous.  I don't have a really strong feeling here, but I think for an admin I am ok returning 'None' for cluster because it is true, it isn't in a cluster.

Right, I was thinking of just handling it here in the view, that is, if cluster_name is None, don't add it to the view even if this is an admin call, mainly because you can't just ask for mv 3.61 *only*, if you're using mv 3.62, you get 3.61 as well.  So my questions are:

(1) For people not running in A/A, will '"cluster_name": null' in the volume-show API response make an admin think something is wrong?

(2) For people running in A/A, does '"cluster_name": null' in the volume-show response give them better info than if that field is just not there at all when there's no cluster_name on that volume?

Don't mean to be a PITA, but just want to make sure we've thought about this carefully, because once this API change merges, we are stuck with it!

/COMMIT_MSG.message: How will we differentiate between upgrade and FFU? Does it perhaps make sense to just see everything as an upgrade?

Could we not end up doing something like:

1. Check current version (somehow)
2. If current version is stein, then do these validations.
3. If current version is rocky, then do these validations.
4. If current version is queens then do these validations.
5. Do validations that apply to all versions.

This would still be 'upgrade' validations... they would just have subtasks which adapt based on where we start.

Good question. Or, asked differently:
are there any existing or planned validations being specific to any of the FFU stages?

Same for the *-system-* - anything that wouldn't be linked to the standard update/upgrade existing groups?

Well, for the ffu upgrade prepare and converge steps, there will definetely be different validations. As the procedure is different from the upgrade and we rely on the _stein parameters to tell tht to run FFU or a simple upgrade, we will have few validations which will differ from an upgrade. Also, the overcloud_ffu_upgrade validations will run node by node, which in the case of a normal upgrade would be executed for the whole overcloud (or a role only, Controllers, Compute, etc...) Another question is, taking into account everything will be FFUs from now onwards maybe it makes sense to not differentiate them and forget about the N to N+1 upgrade.
The system upgrade could be more generic















.
we should NOT put any suck intelligence in validations imho. KISS is the key. If we start doing complicated things now, they will bite us back in the future.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_container_.message: If podman-docker is installed, this will error because it'll invoke podman instead of docker. The logic was correct, the bug would be that there is a `podman` which actually points to `docker`

Right - the check may have to do something like:

if podman is available as a command, and that command is not a symlink, then...
else if docker is available as a command, and that command is not a symlink, then ...
endif

I think the 'else if' is also important here to prevent both trying to execute. This should always be an either/or situation.

So perhaps something like:

  if command -v podman &>/dev/null && [[ ! -h $(command -v podman) ]] && podman exec {{ container }} /bin/true; then
  ...

The operation will fail. There will be 14 reattempts 10 minutes apart (cover over 2 hours) in hope the subcloud comes back ok. Then the subcloud will be mark out-of-sync on dc-cert. The cert-mon behaves in 2 role on system controller, one is the same as it works on subclouds, it monitors admin endpoint cert renew, and talk to sysinv (regionone) to perform the update. The 2nd role is to monitor subcloud ICA, and invokes subcloud sysinv-api (region=subcloud(n)) to perform update. btw, the 2 hour period reattempt is design for avoid a subcloud being offline for upgrade/reboot etc. If it is offline longer than 2 hours, we would not try to predict when it comes back online. README.md.message:
The commit message says "if, and only if, 'data-port' is set, then the 'ext-port' config option is ignored."

How can 'ext-port' be ignored if it was not set?

Do you mean if *both* options are set then 'data-port' takes precedence?

So is a message logged when both are set then? And does this lead to a fatal error?

I can answer this, as I believe it's the same approach as my original patch:

If 'data-port' is set then only the information is used from 'data-port'; 'ext-port' is ignored.  The rest is at it says it is.  No, it doesn't lead to a fatal error.  The charm uses the information in data-port, ignores ext-port, logs an error, and the status line says that the charm is misconfigured.

Aurelien, we're unlikely to stop supporting ext-port as it will break systems on upgrade.  We can log it if you really want to, but it just becomes extra noise in the logs, that will be ignored until something breaks.  We do have it in the release notes and in the config.yaml, that it is deprecated.

Now if juju supported a way to migrate config on charm upgrade, we could re-write the ext-port INTO the data-port and solve the problem; sadly we can't (at present).

Actually, no don't change that.  For existing systems that were set up using the ext-port there is no particular reason for them to change it.  The point of this patchset is IF the user uses data-port, then that's preferred, but if it's not set, then ext-port is perfectly fine to use and IS supported.

I think it's not "perfectly fine" actually because we have decided here to deprecate it. So we should shout that deprecation wherever we can so that the users have enough time to move away from 'ext-port' before we actually stop supporting it.

I'm not religious about it though so this will be my last objection :)

I noticed that the idiom "if and only if" (necessary and sufficient condition) often leads to misunderstandings. But here in the readme we don't use it so I think it's fine. I'll just fix the 'mis-configuration' typo.

Also Peter is right: we could simply always log that deprecation warning if and only if (hehe sorry) 'ext-port' is set to get people away from using it. I'll change that.
What happens if just 'ext-port' is set? How do we get people away from using that option in order to eventually just support 'data-port'?

hooks/neutron_utils.py.message:
It's not really a good idea to implement hidden/internal functions, as they are harder to unit test.

However, bearing in mind my comment further down, it may be that this function is split into two anyway.  I still think they should be module level helper functions.
Yes, obsessing with DRY made me write this :) I think I've now pushed a more elegant solution. Thanks!
I'd make this a WARNING rather than DEBUG.

This feels a bit odd.  At this point it is known whether the port is a linux bridge.  However, it then calls a single function with a param to indicate a linux bridge that then uses that info to call one of two functions.

I think the code might be a bit easier to understand if the code kept the two paths separate from this point forward rather than going back into a single function.
is it odd? I often format this way, but ok I'll try differently

I would avoid using mutable defaults at all cost, take a look at this post [0] for background on why.

You could set it to a None default in the function definition and then add something like this to the top of the function:

    external_id_value = external_id_value or 'managed'

0: https://florimond.dev/blog/articles/2018/08/python-mutable-defaults-are-the-source-of-all-evil/

doc/ext/extra_specs.py.message:
nit the should be count=2

using keyword argments as positionals is a code smell and actually dangouous or at least fragile as the expectaion is the order that keyword arguments are listed in a function defintion should not matter since but when they are treated as postianl like this it will break.

that said looking at the rendering  where this this used in the follow up it looks good to me.

https://33563ef9b3f744137075-b42c6b31cdcfa4f4b221838bf717961f.ssl.cf2.rackcdn.com/722187/9/check/openstack-tox-docs/53b6f03/docs/configuration/extra-specs.html#others-uncategorized

i think should is still correct but this is minor enought that its fine for now.

i kind of wish we had a hacking check that enforced that we only use keyword arguments via keywords but since we dont ill drop my -1

*could be

Python supports keyword-only arguments [1] and positional-only arguments [2]. This is neither, so calling things this was is perfectly fine. Now, if there were multiple arguments here, I'd be more inclined to agree with you, simply for readability if noting else. As-is though, this is perfectly fine :)

[1] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3102/
[2] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0570/
